paragraphs.text: The measure was met with opposition by several interest groups representing the biotechnology industry, The California Plant Health Association (now the Western Plant Health Association) and CropLife America, a Washington-based consortium whose clients represent some of the largest food distributors in the nation, including Monsanto, DuPont and Dow Chemical.

paragraphs.title: Kansas City metropolitan area

paragraphs.title: University of Missouri–Kansas City
paragraphs.text: UMKC is spread across multiple locales; the main Volker Campus, home to the majority of university operations, is located in Kansas City's Rockhill neighborhood, east of the Country Club Plaza, and adjacent to both the Stowers Institute for Medical Research and the world-renowned Linda Hall Library.

paragraphs.title: University of Missouri–Kansas City
paragraphs.text: In 2017 the University, in collaboration with Truman Medical Center, Children's Mercy Hospital, the Missouri Health Department, the Jackson County Medical Examiners Office, and the Missouri Department of Mental Health Behavioral Medicine, formed the UMKC Health Sciences District on Hospital Hill.

paragraphs.title: University of Missouri–Kansas City
paragraphs.text: This district is a first-in-the-nation partnership between local and state governments, the university, and these nationally recognized healthcare faculties, designed to promote collaboration in research, innovation, education, grant funding, and community outreach, for the advancement of health and wellness in the greater Kansas City metropolitan area.

paragraphs.title: Kansas City jazz
paragraphs.text: Kansas City jazz is a style of jazz that developed in Kansas City, Kansas and Kansas City, Missouri and the surrounding Kansas City Metropolitan Area during the 1930s and marked the transition from the structured big band style to the musical improvisation style of Bebop.

paragraphs.title: Kansas City jazz
paragraphs.text: The hard-swinging, bluesy transition style is bracketed by Count Basie who in 1929 signed with the Bennie Moten's Kansas City Orchestra and Kansas City native Charlie Parker who was to usher in the Bebop style in the 1940s.

paragraphs.title: Kansas City jazz
paragraphs.text: According to a Kansas City website, "While New Orleans was the birthplace of jazz, America's music grew up in Kansas City".

paragraphs.title: Kansas City Scout
paragraphs.text: Kansas City Scout is one of the United States' largest electronic traffic management systems.

paragraphs.title: Kansas City Scout
paragraphs.text: It was created in 2000 as part of a bi-state initiative between the Missouri Department of Transportation and the Kansas Department of Transportation to provide this system for the Kansas City Metropolitan Area, which is in both Missouri and Kansas (the anchor city of Kansas City is in Missouri).

paragraphs.title: Kansas City Scout
paragraphs.text: The project's cost was $43 million.

paragraphs.title: Kansas City Scout
paragraphs.text: Of that amount, the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA) contributed 80-90 percent of the project cost.

paragraphs.title: Kansas City Scout
paragraphs.text: KDOT and MoDOT shared the remaining cost.

paragraphs.title: Kansas City Scout
paragraphs.text: The system employs a system of electronic boards placed on major highways throughout the metropolitan area that display traffic information whenever information needs to be displayed (due to an accident, lane closure, highway closure etc.), and the system also has cameras on those billboards to automatically detect traffic problems.

paragraphs.title: Kansas City Scout
paragraphs.text: While the system has extensive coverage of highways in the Kansas City Metropolitan Area it still has much more to cover.

paragraphs.title: Kansas City Scout
paragraphs.text: Since it would be too expensive to cover all the major highways in the Kansas City metro (which has more miles of highway per person than any other metropolitan area in the United States), studies were conducted to determine which highways or segments of highways have priority due to higher accident rates.

paragraphs.title: Kansas City Scout
paragraphs.text: Since the project's beginning, it has expanded greatly, and will continue to expand.

paragraphs.title: Kansas City Scout
paragraphs.text: Future plans are to extend coverage to I-635 and cover I-435 even more (especially in the northern areas of the metro) as well as other major city highways.

paragraphs.title: Kansas City Scout
paragraphs.text: It was named after the iconic Kansas City Scout Statue that exists in Penn Valley Park, overlooking Downtown Kansas City.

paragraphs.title: Remote control
paragraphs.text: In electronics, a remote control is a component of an electronic device used to operate the device wirelessly from a distance.

paragraphs.title: Remote control
paragraphs.text: For example, in consumer electronics, a remote control can be used to operate devices such as a television set, DVD player, or other home appliance, from a short distance.

paragraphs.title: Remote control
paragraphs.text: A remote control is primarily a convenience feature for the user, and can allow operation of devices that are out of convenient reach for direct operation of controls.

paragraphs.title: Remote control
paragraphs.text: In some cases, remote controls allow a person to operate a device that they otherwise would not be able to reach, as when a garage door opener is triggered from outside or when a Digital Light Processing projector that is mounted on a high ceiling is controlled by a person from the floor level.

paragraphs.title: Front Row (software)
paragraphs.text: Front Row is a discontinued media center software application for Apple's Macintosh computers and Apple TV for navigating and viewing video, photos, podcasts, and music from a computer, optical disc, or the Internet through a 10-foot user interface (similar to Windows Media Center and Kodi).

paragraphs.title: Universal remote

paragraphs.title: Universal remote
paragraphs.text: Low-end universal remotes can only control a set number of devices determined by their manufacturer, while mid- and high-end universal remotes allow the user to program in new control codes to the remote.

paragraphs.title: Universal remote

paragraphs.title: Universal remote
paragraphs.text: For example, a VCR remote may be programmed to operate various brands of televisions.

paragraphs.title: Apple Watch

paragraphs.title: Trainmaster Command Control
paragraphs.text: Trainmaster Command (TMCC) is Lionel's electronic control system for O scale 3-rail model trains and toy trains that mainly ran from 1994 to 2006.

paragraphs.title: Trainmaster Command Control
paragraphs.text: Conceptually it is similar to Digital Command Control (DCC), the industry's open standard used by HO scale and other 2-rail DC trains.

paragraphs.title: Trainmaster Command Control
paragraphs.text: It has one advantage over DCC, in that TMCC-equipped locomotives can run simultaneously with non-TMCC locomotives and Lionel Legacy engines as well as LionChief and LionChief Plus equipped locomotives.

paragraphs.title: Trainmaster Command Control
paragraphs.text: The latter require a dedicated remote controller.

paragraphs.title: Trainmaster Command Control
paragraphs.text: MTH Corporation's DCS controller can be configured to control TMCC locomotives, and all four systems (TMCC, Legacy, LionChief/LionChief+ and DCS) can be operated on the same track simultaneously.

paragraphs.title: Trainmaster Command Control
paragraphs.text: Each simply requires a constant track voltage (18 volts).

paragraphs.title: Trainmaster Command Control
paragraphs.text: TMCC/Legacy "broadcasts" it's signal to the antenna on the locomotives which listen for signals that first identify the particular locomotive by number and then it issues given commands as to speed, direction, sounds, lighting and other features.

paragraphs.title: Trainmaster Command Control
paragraphs.text: DCS performs similar functions but transmits a carrier over the rails which are picked up through the locomotive's electrical pickup contacts.

paragraphs.title: Trainmaster Command Control
paragraphs.text: While TMCC/Legacy and DCS remote controls relay operator commands to a device that transmits them to the train (Command Base or Track Interface Unit), LionChief/LionChief+ also issue remote control commands but the remote and locomotive are married and each locomotive requires a separate remote control.

paragraphs.title: Trainmaster Command Control
paragraphs.text: This system requires no additional wiring as the control is directly "narrowcast" to the locomotive in the same way as a television remote control or garage door opener functions.

paragraphs.title: Trainmaster Command Control
paragraphs.text: In 2017, Lionel released a universal remote for LionChief+ that will learn addresses for up to three locos at a time, simplifying the operation of multiple trains.

paragraphs.title: Death of Abdul Wali
paragraphs.text: Abdul Wali was an Afghan man who died in US custody on June 21, 2003 at the age of 28.

paragraphs.title: Death of Abdul Wali
paragraphs.text: At the time of his death, he had been held for three days at the US base 10 miles south of Asadabad, in Kunar Province, Afghanistan, on suspicion of involvement in a rocket attack on the same base.

paragraphs.title: Death of Abdul Wali
paragraphs.text: The cause of his death was at first reported to be a heart attack, but this came into question when three members of the U.S. 82nd Airborne Division came forward to testify that CIA contractor David Passaro assaulted Wali.

paragraphs.title: Death of Abdul Wali
paragraphs.text: Passaro, a former U.S. Army Ranger, allegedly beat Wali for two consecutive nights, causing grievous injuries including a fractured pelvis.

paragraphs.title: Death of Abdul Wali
paragraphs.text: Prosecutors would charge that Passaro ordered soldiers not to allow Wali to sleep, limited his access to food and water and subjected him to two consecutive nights of interrogation and beatings.

paragraphs.title: Death of Abdul Wali
paragraphs.text: Among other injuries, Wali suffered a suspected fractured pelvis that would have made it impossible for him to urinate.

paragraphs.title: Death of Abdul Wali
paragraphs.text: Witnesses testified that during one session Passaro, while wearing combat boots, kicked Wali in the groin hard enough to lift him off the ground, threw Wali to the ground, beat Wali on the arms and legs with a heavy Maglite flashlight, and that Passaro also vigorously thrust a flashlight into Wali's abdomen.

paragraphs.title: Death of Abdul Wali
paragraphs.text: After the second night of beatings, Wali begged the soldiers to kill him and moaned a phrase that meant, "I'm dying."

paragraphs.title: Death of Abdul Wali
paragraphs.text: Wali died on his fourth day in custody.

paragraphs.title: Death of Abdul Wali
paragraphs.text: He repeatedly denied any involvement in the rocket attacks.

paragraphs.title: Alexander Kerensky

paragraphs.title: Alexander Kerensky
paragraphs.text: After the February Revolution of 1917 he joined the newly formed Russian Provisional Government, first as Minister of Justice, then as Minister of War, and after July 1917 as the government's second Minister-Chairman.

paragraphs.title: Alexander Kerensky
paragraphs.text: A leader of the moderate-socialist Trudoviks faction of the Socialist Revolutionary Party, he was also vice-chairman of the powerful Petrograd Soviet.

paragraphs.title: Timofey Samsonov

paragraphs.title: Lavr Kornilov
paragraphs.text: He is today best remembered for the Kornilov Affair, an unsuccessful endeavor in August/September 1917 that purported to strengthen Alexander Kerensky's Provisional Government, but which led to Kerensky eventually having Kornilov arrested and charged with attempting a coup d'état, and ultimately undermined the rule of Kerensky; strengthening the claims and power of the soviets, and the Bolshevik party.

paragraphs.title: Left-wing uprisings against the Bolsheviks
paragraphs.text: The left-wing uprisings against the Bolsheviks were a series of rebellions and uprisings against the Bolsheviks by rival left-wing parties that started soon after the October Revolution, continued through the Russian Civil War, and lasted into the first few years of Soviet rule.

paragraphs.title: Left-wing uprisings against the Bolsheviks
paragraphs.text: They were led or supported by left-wing groups such as some factions of the Socialist Revolutionary Party, Left Socialist Revolutionaries, Mensheviks, and anarchists.

paragraphs.title: Left-wing uprisings against the Bolsheviks
paragraphs.text: The uprisings started in 1918 and continued during and after the Civil War until around 1924.

paragraphs.title: Left-wing uprisings against the Bolsheviks

paragraphs.title: Socialist Revolutionary Party
paragraphs.text: The Socialist Revolutionary Party, or Party of Socialists-Revolutionaries (the SRs; Russian: Партия социалистов-революционеров (ПСР), эсеры , "esery") was a major political party in early 20th century Russia and a key player in the Russian Revolution.

paragraphs.title: Socialist Revolutionary Party
paragraphs.text: Its general ideology was revolutionary socialism of democratic socialist and agrarian socialist forms.

paragraphs.title: Socialist Revolutionary Party
paragraphs.text: After the February Revolution of 1917, it shared power with other liberal and democratic socialist forces within the Russian Provisional Government.

paragraphs.title: Socialist Revolutionary Party
paragraphs.text: In November 1917, it won a plurality of the national vote in Russia's first-ever democratic elections (to the Russian Constituent Assembly), but the October Revolution had changed the political landscape and the Bolsheviks disbanded the Constituent Assembly in January 1918.

paragraphs.title: Socialist Revolutionary Party
paragraphs.text: The SRs soon split into pro-Bolshevik and anti-Bolshevik factions.

paragraphs.title: Socialist Revolutionary Party
paragraphs.text: The anti-Bolshevik faction of this party, known as the Right SRs, which remained loyal to the Provisional Government leader Alexander Kerensky was defeated and destroyed by the Bolsheviks in the course of the Russian Civil War and subsequent persecution.

paragraphs.title: Kerensky–Krasnov uprising
paragraphs.text: Kerensky–Krasnov uprising was an attempt by Alexander Kerensky to regain power after the Bolsheviks overthrew his Provisional Government in Petrograd.

paragraphs.title: Louise Bryant

paragraphs.title: Russian Civil War
paragraphs.text: The Russian Civil War (Russian: Гражда́нская война́ в Росси́и , "Grazhdanskaya voyna v Rossiyi" ; November 1917 – October 1922) was a multi-party war in the former Russian Empire immediately after the Russian Revolutions of 1917, as many factions vied to determine Russia's political future.

paragraphs.title: Russian Civil War
paragraphs.text: The two largest combatant groups were the Red Army, fighting for the Bolshevik form of socialism led by Vladimir Lenin, and the loosely allied forces known as the White Army, which included diverse interests favoring monarchism, capitalism and alternative forms of socialism, each with democratic and antidemocratic variants.

paragraphs.title: Russian Civil War
paragraphs.text: In addition, rival militant socialists and nonideological Green armies fought against both the Bolsheviks and the Whites.

paragraphs.title: Russian Civil War
paragraphs.text: Eight foreign nations intervened against the Red Army, notably the Allied Forces and the pro-German armies.

paragraphs.title: Russian Civil War
paragraphs.text: The Red Army defeated the White Armed Forces of South Russia in Ukraine and the army led by Admiral Aleksandr Kolchak in Siberia in 1919.

paragraphs.title: Russian Civil War
paragraphs.text: The remains of the White forces commanded by Pyotr Nikolayevich Wrangel were beaten in Crimea and evacuated in late 1920.

paragraphs.title: Russian Civil War
paragraphs.text: Lesser battles of the war continued on the periphery for two more years, and minor skirmishes with the remnants of the White forces in the Far East continued well into 1923.

paragraphs.title: Russian Civil War
paragraphs.text: The war ended in 1923 in the sense that Red control of the newly formed Soviet Union was now assured, although armed national resistance in Central Asia was not completely crushed until 1934.

paragraphs.title: Russian Civil War
paragraphs.text: There were an estimated 7,000,000–12,000,000 casualties during the war, mostly civilians.

paragraphs.title: Russian Civil War
paragraphs.text: The Russian Civil War has been described by some as the greatest national catastrophe that Europe had yet seen.

paragraphs.title: Battle of Romanovka
paragraphs.text: The Battle of Romanovka was fought in June 1919 during the Russian Civil War.

paragraphs.title: Battle of Romanovka
paragraphs.text: Russian Bolsheviks of Yakov Triapitsyn launched a surprise attack on an American army camp at Romanovka, Siberia near Vladivostok.

paragraphs.title: Battle of Romanovka
paragraphs.text: As a result of the engagement, the attacks were repelled.

paragraphs.title: Battle of Romanovka
paragraphs.text: Romanovka and the Suchan Valley Campaign that followed were the final major engagements of the Russian Civil War involving the United States.

paragraphs.title: Battle of Romanovka
paragraphs.text: Battles would later break out again between the Americans and Bolsheviks, as well as the Cossacks, on much smaller scales.

paragraphs.text: In 1978, he moved to the United States and began work at Brookhaven National Laboratory, where he was an Associate Chairman of the National Synchrotron Light Source and co-director at the Center for Accelerator Physics.

paragraphs.title: Claudio Pellegrini
paragraphs.text: In 1989, he accepted an appointment at the University of California at Los Angeles (UCLA) as a professor of physics, and later became a Distinguished Professor.

paragraphs.title: Enrico Fermi
paragraphs.text: Enrico Fermi ( ; ] ; 29 September 1901 – 28 November 1954) was an Italian physicist and the creator of the world's first nuclear reactor, the Chicago Pile-1.

paragraphs.title: Enrico Fermi
paragraphs.text: He has been called the "architect of the nuclear age" and the "architect of the atomic bomb".

paragraphs.title: Enrico Fermi
paragraphs.text: He was one of the very few physicists in history to excel both theoretically and experimentally.

paragraphs.title: Enrico Fermi
paragraphs.text: Fermi held several patents related to the use of nuclear power, and was awarded the 1938 Nobel Prize in Physics for his work on induced radioactivity by neutron bombardment and the discovery of transuranic elements.

paragraphs.title: Enrico Fermi
paragraphs.text: He made significant contributions to the development of quantum theory, nuclear and particle physics, and statistical mechanics.

paragraphs.title: Sergio Ferrara
paragraphs.text: Sergio Ferrara (born May 2, 1945) is an Italian physicist working on theoretical physics of elementary particles and mathematical physics.

paragraphs.title: Sergio Ferrara
paragraphs.text: He is renowned for the discovery of theories introducing supersymmetry as a symmetry of elementary particles (super-Yang–Mills theories, together with Bruno Zumino) and of supergravity, the first significant extension of Einstein's general relativity, based on the principle of "local supersymmetry" (together with Daniel Z. Freedman, and Peter van Nieuwenhuizen).

paragraphs.title: Sergio Ferrara
paragraphs.text: He is an emeritus staff member at CERN and a professor at the University of California, Los Angeles.

paragraphs.title: Luciano Pietronero
paragraphs.text: Luciano Pietronero (born in Rome on December 15, 1949) is an Italian physicist (statistical physics) and full professor at the department of Physics at University of Rome "Sapienza".

question: The Livesey Hal War Memorial commemorates the fallen of which war, that had over 60 million casualties?

paragraphs.title: Tower Hill Memorial
paragraphs.text: The Tower Hill Memorial is a Commonwealth War Graves Commission war memorial on the south side of Trinity Square Gardens, in London, England.

paragraphs.title: Tower Hill Memorial
paragraphs.text: The memorial commemorates those from the Merchant Navy and fishing fleets who died during both world wars and have "no grave but the sea".

paragraphs.title: Tower Hill Memorial
paragraphs.text: The memorial was designed by Edwin Lutyens with sculpture work by William Reid Dick, the Second World War extension was designed by Edward Maufe with sculpture work by Charles Wheeler.

paragraphs.title: Rainham War Memorial
paragraphs.text: The Rainham War Memorial commemorates soldiers killed in both World Wars as well as civilian casualties of World War II.

paragraphs.title: Freetown Memorial
paragraphs.text: The Freetown Memorial is a Commonwealth War Graves Commission war memorial located outside the Secretariate Building in Freetown, Sierra Leone.

paragraphs.title: Freetown Memorial
paragraphs.text: The memorial generally commemorates Soldiers from Sierra Leone who died whilst serving with the Royal West African Frontier Force in West Africa and whose graves are not known.

paragraphs.title: Freetown Memorial
paragraphs.text: The Freetown Memorial commemorates 1,109 First World War casualties and 247 from the Second World War.

paragraphs.title: Monmouth War Memorial
paragraphs.text: The Monmouth War Memorial commemorates the Monmouth fallen of the First and Second World Wars.

paragraphs.title: Arras Flying Services Memorial
paragraphs.text: The Arras Flying Services Memorial Commonwealth War Graves Commission war memorial in the Faubourg d'Amiens Cemetery, Arras, France.

paragraphs.title: Arras Flying Services Memorial
paragraphs.text: The memorial commemorates nearly 1,000 airmen from forces of the Commonwealth who were killed on the Western Front during World War I and who have no known grave.

paragraphs.title: Arras Flying Services Memorial
paragraphs.text: The memorial was designed by Edwin Lutyens, sculpted by William Reid Dick and unveiled by Hugh Trenchard, 1st Viscount Trenchard, Marshal of the Royal Air Force on 31 July 1932.

paragraphs.title: Livesey Hall War Memorial
paragraphs.text: The Livesey Hall War Memorial commemorates the fallen of World War I and World War II who had been employed by the South Suburban Gas Company of London.

paragraphs.title: Livesey Hall War Memorial
paragraphs.text: It is also a tribute to those employees who served in the wars.

paragraphs.title: Livesey Hall War Memorial
paragraphs.text: The monument was designed and executed by British sculptor Sydney March, of the March family of artists.

paragraphs.title: Portsmouth Naval Memorial
paragraphs.text: The Portsmouth Naval Memorial, sometimes known as Southsea Naval Memorial, is a war memorial in Portsmouth, Hampshire, England, on Southsea Common beside Clarence Esplanade, between Clarence Pier and Southsea Castle.

paragraphs.title: Portsmouth Naval Memorial
paragraphs.text: The memorial commemorates approximately 25,000 British and Commonwealth sailors who were lost in the World Wars, around 10,000 sailors in the First World War and 15,000 in the Second World War.

paragraphs.title: Portsmouth Naval Memorial
paragraphs.text: The memorial features a central obelisk, with names of the dead on bronze plaques arranged around the memorial according to the year of death.

paragraphs.title: Masnières Newfoundland Memorial
paragraphs.text: The Masnières Newfoundland Memorial is a Dominion of Newfoundland war memorial that commemorates the actions of the Royal Newfoundland Regiment during the First Battle of Cambrai, of World War I.

paragraphs.title: Masnières Newfoundland Memorial
paragraphs.text: Located at the north end of the town of Masnières, France, the memorial commemorates the participation of the Newfoundlanders in the taking and defense of the town during the First Battle of Cambrai between the 20th of November and 2 December 1917.

paragraphs.title: Vietnam War Memorial, Hanoi
paragraphs.text: The War Memorial in Hanoi is located across the Ba Dinh Square, across the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and close to Hanoi Citadel.

paragraphs.title: Vietnam War Memorial, Hanoi
paragraphs.text: Constructed in 1993 in a fusion of traditional Vietnamese and modernist architecture, the memorial commemorates men and women who sacrificed themselves during the Second Indochina War.

paragraphs.title: Vietnam War Memorial, Hanoi
paragraphs.text: The war is known by many names, e.g. as the American War in Vietnam.

paragraphs.title: Vietnam War Memorial, Hanoi
paragraphs.text: The memorial is a focal point for state functions, commemorating the war dead.

paragraphs.title: Alamein Memorial
paragraphs.text: The Alamein Memorial is a Commonwealth War Graves Commission war memorial in the El Alamein War Cemetery, El Alamein, Egypt.

paragraphs.title: Alamein Memorial
paragraphs.text: The memorial commemorates 11,866 Commonwealth forces members who died during World War II.

paragraphs.title: Alamein Memorial
paragraphs.text: The memorial was designed by Hubert Worthington and unveiled by Viscount Montgomery of Alamein on 24 October 1954.

question: Are both Elko Regional Airport and Gerald R. Ford International Airport located in Michigan?

paragraphs.title: Gerald R. Ford Presidential Library
paragraphs.text: The Gerald R. Ford Presidential Library is a repository located on the north campus of the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor.

paragraphs.title: Gerald R. Ford Presidential Library
paragraphs.text: The library houses archival materials on the life, career, and presidency of Gerald Ford, the 38th President of the United States.

paragraphs.title: Gerald R. Ford Presidential Library
paragraphs.text: The Gerald R. Ford Presidential Library is a part of the National Archives and Records Administration's presidential library system.

paragraphs.title: Grantley Adams International Airport
paragraphs.text: Grantley Adams International Airport (GAIA) (IATA: BGI, ICAO: TBPB) is the international airport of Barbados, located in Seawell, Christ Church.

paragraphs.title: Grantley Adams International Airport
paragraphs.text: It is the only designated port of entry for persons arriving and departing by air in Barbados and operates as a major gateway to the Eastern Caribbean.

paragraphs.title: Grantley Adams International Airport
paragraphs.text: The airport has direct service to destinations in the United States, Canada, Central America and Europe and serves as the second hub for LIAT.

paragraphs.title: Grantley Adams International Airport
paragraphs.text: In 2016, the airport was the 8th busiest airport in the Caribbean region; and the third busiest airport in the Lesser Antilles; after Queen Beatrix International Airport located in Aruba, and Pointe-à-Pitre International Airport located in the Republic of France within the island of Guadeloupe.

paragraphs.title: Grantley Adams International Airport
paragraphs.text: GAIA, also remains an important air-link for cruise ship passengers departing and arriving at the Port of Bridgetown, and a base of operations for the Regional Security System (RSS), and the Regional (Caribbean) Police Training Centre.

paragraphs.title: Pre-Commissioning Unit
paragraphs.text: A pre-commissioning unit (PRECOMMUNIT) or (PCU) is used by the United States Navy to describe vessels under construction prior to their official commissioning.

paragraphs.title: Pre-Commissioning Unit
paragraphs.text: For example, prior to its commissioning, the aircraft carrier "Gerald R. Ford" (CVN-78) has been described by the Navy as "pre-commissioning unit (PCU) "Gerald R. Ford" ."

paragraphs.title: Pre-Commissioning Unit
paragraphs.text: However, "PCU" is only a descriptive term and is not a prefix or a part of the ship's official name.

paragraphs.title: Pre-Commissioning Unit
paragraphs.text: Until they are commissioned, U.S. Navy vessels are officially identified by their given name and hull number only with no prefix, such as "Gerald R. Ford" (CVN-78).

paragraphs.title: Gerald R. Ford International Airport
paragraphs.text: Gerald R. Ford International Airport (IATA: GRR, ICAO: KGRR, FAA LID: GRR) is a commercial airport in Cascade Township approximately 13 mi southeast of Grand Rapids, Michigan.

paragraphs.title: Gerald R. Ford International Airport
paragraphs.text: The facility is owned by the Kent County Board of Commissioners and managed by an independent authority.

paragraphs.title: Gerald R. Ford International Airport
paragraphs.text: The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems for 2017–2021 categorized it as a small hub primary commercial service facility.

paragraphs.title: Gerald R. Ford Freeway
paragraphs.text: The Gerald R. Ford Freeway refers to Interstate Highways named for former President Gerald R. Ford in Omaha (where he was born) and Michigan (where he grew up and was a Congressman):

paragraphs.title: Bishop International Airport
paragraphs.text: Bishop International Airport (IATA: FNT, ICAO: KFNT, FAA LID: FNT) is a commercial and general aviation airport located in Flint, Michigan.

paragraphs.title: Bishop International Airport
paragraphs.text: It is named after banker and General Motors board member Arthur Giles Bishop (April 12, 1851 – January 22, 1944), who donated 220 acres of his farmland for the airport in 1928.

paragraphs.title: Bishop International Airport
paragraphs.text: The third busiest airport in Michigan, it surpassed competitor MBS International Airport in terms of airline operations in 2002.

paragraphs.title: Bishop International Airport
paragraphs.text: In 2007, 1,071,238 passengers used Bishop International Airport; in 2011, 938,914 passengers used the airport.

paragraphs.title: Bishop International Airport
paragraphs.text: It is included in the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems for 2017–2021, in which it is categorized as a small hub primary commercial service facility.

paragraphs.title: Bishop International Airport
paragraphs.text: The airport is currently served by several passenger airlines: Allegiant Air, Southwest Airlines and Delta Air Lines operate mainline service out of the airport, as well as affiliates of Delta Connection, United Express and American Eagle.

paragraphs.title: Bishop International Airport
paragraphs.text: Additionally, FedEx Express and a FedEx Feeder affiliate operate cargo services out of the airport.

paragraphs.title: Bishop International Airport
paragraphs.text: Accompanying the airlines is fixed-base operator Av Flight that handles both general aviation and airline operations and the flight school American Wings Aviation.

paragraphs.title: Bishop International Airport
paragraphs.text: Bishop International Airport is in southwestern Flint, and is surrounded by Flint Township to the north, east and west; and Mundy Township to the south.

paragraphs.title: Raleigh Executive Jetport
paragraphs.text: Raleigh Exec: The Raleigh Executive Jetport @ Sanford-Lee County or Raleigh Exec Jetport at Sanford-Lee CountyFAA Airport Master Record for TTA (Form 5010 ) (ICAO: KTTA, FAA LID: TTA) is a public use airport located seven nautical miles (8 mi, 13 km) northeast of the central business district of Sanford, a city in Lee County, North Carolina, United States.

paragraphs.title: Raleigh Executive Jetport
paragraphs.text: It is owned by the Sanford-Lee County Regional Airport Authority and was previously known as Sanford-Lee County Regional Airport.

paragraphs.title: Raleigh Executive Jetport
paragraphs.text: This airport is included in the National Plan of Integrated Airport Systems for 2011–2015, which categorized it as a "reliever airport" for Raleigh-Durham International Airport.

paragraphs.title: John Glenn Columbus International Airport
paragraphs.text: John Glenn Columbus International Airport (IATA: CMH, ICAO: KCMH, FAA LID: CMH) , is an international airport located 6 mi east of downtown Columbus, Ohio.

paragraphs.title: John Glenn Columbus International Airport
paragraphs.text: Formerly known as Port Columbus International Airport, it is managed by the Columbus Regional Airport Authority, which also oversees operations at Rickenbacker International Airport and Bolton Field.

paragraphs.title: John Glenn Columbus International Airport
paragraphs.text: The airport code 'CMH' stands for "Columbus Municipal Hangar," the original name for the airport.

paragraphs.title: Elko Regional Airport
paragraphs.text: Elko Regional Airport (IATA: EKO, ICAO: KEKO, FAA LID: EKO) , formerly Elko Municipal Airport, is a mile west of downtown Elko, in Elko County, Nevada.

paragraphs.title: Pensacola International Airport
paragraphs.text: Pensacola International Airport (IATA: PNS, ICAO: KPNS, FAA LID: PNS) , formerly Pensacola Gulf Coast Regional Airport and Pensacola Regional Airport (Hagler Field), is a public use airport three nautical miles (6 km) northeast of the central business district of Pensacola, in Escambia County, Florida, United States.

paragraphs.title: Pensacola International Airport
paragraphs.text: It is owned by the City of Pensacola.

paragraphs.title: Pensacola International Airport
paragraphs.text: Despite the name, this airport does not offer direct international flights.

paragraphs.title: Pensacola International Airport
paragraphs.text: This airport is one of the five major airports in North Florida, others being: Northwest Florida Beaches International Airport, Destin-Fort Walton Beach Airport Tallahassee International Airport, and Jacksonville International Airport.

question: Ralph Hefferline was a psychology professor at a university that is located in what city?

paragraphs.title: Princeton Neuroscience Institute
paragraphs.text: The Princeton Neuroscience Institute (PNI) is a center for neuroscience research at Princeton University.

paragraphs.title: Princeton Neuroscience Institute
paragraphs.text: PNI was created in 2006 as a partnership of Princeton University's departments of Psychology and Molecular Biology.

paragraphs.title: Princeton Neuroscience Institute
paragraphs.text: This partnership was led by psychology professor Jonathan Cohen and molecular biology professor David Tank, who continue to serve as Co-Directors of the Institute.

paragraphs.title: Princeton Neuroscience Institute
paragraphs.text: In 2014, PNI moved into a dedicated research complex that houses both PNI and the Department of Psychology.

paragraphs.title: Princeton Neuroscience Institute
paragraphs.text: The building is 248,00 square feet, and was designed by Rafael Moneo to meet LEED Silver certification.

paragraphs.title: Abraham Maslow
paragraphs.text: Abraham Harold Maslow ( ; April 1, 1908 – June 8, 1970) was an American psychologist who was best known for creating Maslow's hierarchy of needs, a theory of psychological health predicated on fulfilling innate human needs in priority, culminating in self-actualization.

paragraphs.title: Abraham Maslow
paragraphs.text: Maslow was a psychology professor at Alliant International University, Brandeis University, Brooklyn College, New School for Social Research, and Columbia University.

paragraphs.title: Abraham Maslow
paragraphs.text: He stressed the importance of focusing on the positive qualities in people, as opposed to treating them as a "bag of symptoms."

paragraphs.title: Abraham Maslow
paragraphs.text: A "Review of General Psychology" survey, published in 2002, ranked Maslow as the tenth most cited psychologist of the 20th century.

paragraphs.title: Frank L. Schmidt
paragraphs.text: Frank L. Schmidt is a retired American psychology professor (University of Iowa) known for his work in personnel selection and employment testing.

paragraphs.title: Frank L. Schmidt
paragraphs.text: Schmidt is a researcher in the area of industrial and organizational psychology with the most number of publications in the two major journals in the 1980s.

paragraphs.title: Frank L. Schmidt
paragraphs.text: In the 1990s he was the 4th most published researcher in Journal of Applied Psychology (JAP) and Personnel Psychology (PP), the two principal publications in the field of industrial-organizational psychology.

paragraphs.title: Frank L. Schmidt
paragraphs.text: He is also winner of the first Dunnette Prize, the most prestigious lifetime achievement award given by the Society for Industrial and Organizational Psychology "to honor living individuals whose work has significantly expanded knowledge of the causal significance of individual differences through advanced research, development, and/or application"

paragraphs.title: Stephen M. Colarelli
paragraphs.text: Stephen M. Colarelli is an American psychology professor at Central Michigan University, known for his research on evolutionary psychology and the workplace.

paragraphs.title: Stanley Coren
paragraphs.text: Stanley Coren (born 1942) is a psychology professor and neuropsychological researcher who has become best known to the general public for his best selling and award-winning books regarding the intelligence, mental abilities and history of dogs. Through television shows and media coverage that have been broadcast in Canada and the United States as well as overseas, he has become popular with dog owners, while continuing research and instruction in psychology at the University of British Columbia in Vancouver, British Columbia.

paragraphs.title: Stanley Coren
paragraphs.text: He also writes for "Psychology Today" in the award-winning regular feature series Canine Corner .

paragraphs.title: Kimberly Young
paragraphs.text: Kimberly Young is a psychologist and world expert on Internet addiction disorder and online behaviour.

paragraphs.title: Kimberly Young
paragraphs.text: She founded the Center for Internet Addiction in 1995 and was a psychology professor at the University of Pittsburgh at Bradford with a PhD in Clinical Psychology.

paragraphs.title: Kimberly Young
paragraphs.text: Young is currently a professor of management scientists at St. Bonaventure University.

paragraphs.title: Kimberly Young
paragraphs.text: She has published numerous journal articles and books chapters and served as an expert witness regarding her pioneer research including testimony for the Child Protection Online Act Congressional Committee.

paragraphs.title: Kimberly Young
paragraphs.text: Young is a member of the American Psychological Association, the Pennsylvania Psychological Association, and a founding member of the International Society of Mental Health Online.

paragraphs.title: Ralph Hefferline
paragraphs.text: Ralph Franklin Hefferline (15 February 1910 in Muncie, Indiana – 16 March 1974) was a psychology professor at Columbia University.

paragraphs.title: Mathematically Alive
paragraphs.text: Mathematically Alive: A Story of Fandom is an award-winning 2007 documentary film about fans of the New York Mets.

paragraphs.title: Mathematically Alive
paragraphs.text: Directed, produced and edited by Katherine Foronjy and Joseph Coburn, the film follows a wide variety of fans over the course of the 2005 and 2006 baseball seasons, culminating in an exciting 7 game series against the St. Louis Cardinals in the NLCS.

paragraphs.title: Mathematically Alive
paragraphs.text: "Mathematically Alive" shows the emotional attachment that fans develop for their team and how it can be the source of great joy or tremendous sadness.

paragraphs.title: Mathematically Alive
paragraphs.text: In addition to the hundreds of fans interviewed for the film, Coburn and Foronjy also caught up with former Mets players Bud Harrelson, Ron Swoboda, Ed Charles, Tim Teuffel and legendary broadcaster Ralph Kiner.

paragraphs.title: Mathematically Alive
paragraphs.text: The filmmakers also interviewed Dr. Daniel Wann, a sports psychology professor at Murray State University, who explains many of the psychological characteristics sports fans share.

paragraphs.title: Mathematically Alive
paragraphs.text: Of particular focus in the film are a group of female Mets fans whose favorite player is former catcher Mike Piazza.

paragraphs.title: Mathematically Alive
paragraphs.text: They wait for his arrival outside the Shea stadium parking lot on game days, and travelled around the country to see him play even when he was no longer a player on the Mets.

paragraphs.title: E. Mavis Hetherington
paragraphs.text: E. Mavis Hetherington (born November 27, 1926) is a retired psychology professor at the University of Virginia.

paragraphs.title: E. Mavis Hetherington
paragraphs.text: She is a leading researcher on the impacts of divorce, family as units, and the development of children.

paragraphs.title: E. Mavis Hetherington
paragraphs.text: Throughout her career she has published more than 200 articles and edited 13 books.

paragraphs.title: E. Mavis Hetherington
paragraphs.text: While a professor at the University of Virginia she helped improve their psychology department, making them a nationally ranked program.

paragraphs.title: E. Mavis Hetherington
paragraphs.text: Hetherington also introduced a new method of analyzing observational research as well as help open the field of psychology to women by overcoming discrimination in her early career.

paragraphs.title: David C. Funder
paragraphs.text: David C. Funder (Ph.D., Stanford University, 1979) is a psychology professor who has written a number of important textbooks and research articles pertaining to the field of personality psychology.

paragraphs.title: David C. Funder
paragraphs.text: Funder resides as the chair of the Psychology department at the University of California, Riverside.

paragraphs.title: David C. Funder
paragraphs.text: He used to be a past editor of the "Journal of Research and Personality", as well as being a former secondary editor of the "Journal of Personality and Social Psychology".

paragraphs.title: David C. Funder
paragraphs.text: Funder has been praised for his studies on personality judgment.

paragraphs.title: David C. Funder
paragraphs.text: He had also published research over the attribution theory and the "delay of gratification".

question: Which dog's ancestors include Gordon and Irish Setters: the Manchester Terrier or the Scotch Collie?

paragraphs.title: Scotch Collie
paragraphs.text: The Scotch Collie is a landrace breed of dog which originated from the highland regions of Scotland.

paragraphs.title: Scotch Collie
paragraphs.text: The breed consisted of both the long-haired (now known as Rough) Collie and the short-haired (now known as Smooth) Collie.

paragraphs.title: Scotch Collie
paragraphs.text: It is generally believed to have descended from a variety of ancient herding dogs, some dating back to the Roman occupation, which may have included Roman Cattle Dogs, Native Celtic Dogs and Viking Herding Spitzes.

paragraphs.title: Scotch Collie
paragraphs.text: Other ancestors include the Gordon and Irish Setters.

paragraphs.title: Collie
paragraphs.text: The collie is a distinctive type of herding dog, including many related landraces and standardised breeds.

paragraphs.title: Collie
paragraphs.text: The type originated in Scotland and Northern England.

paragraphs.title: Collie
paragraphs.text: The collie is a medium-sized, fairly lightly built dog, with a pointed snout.

paragraphs.title: Collie
paragraphs.text: Many types have a distinctive white pattern over the shoulders.

paragraphs.title: Collie
paragraphs.text: Collies are very active and agile, and most types of collies have a very strong herding instinct.

paragraphs.title: Collie
paragraphs.text: Collie breeds have spread through many parts of the world (especially Australia and North America) and have diversified into many varieties, sometimes with mixture from other dog types.

paragraphs.title: Collie
paragraphs.text: Some collie breeds have remained as working dogs, used for herding cattle, sheep and other livestock, while others are kept as pets, show dogs or for dog sports, in which they display great agility, stamina and trainability.

paragraphs.title: Collie
paragraphs.text: While the AKC has a breed they call "Collie", in fact collie dogs are a distinctive type of herding dog including many related landraces and formal breeds.

paragraphs.title: Collie
paragraphs.text: There are usually major distinctions between show dogs and those bred for herding trials or dog sports.

paragraphs.title: Collie
paragraphs.text: They typically display great agility, stamina and trainability and more importantly sagacity.

paragraphs.title: Viol
paragraphs.text: The viol , viola da gamba ] , or (informally) gamba, is any one of a family of bowed, fretted and stringed instruments with hollow wooden bodies and pegboxes where the tension on the strings can be increased or decreased to adjust the pitch of each of the strings.

paragraphs.title: Viol
paragraphs.text: Frets on the viol are usually made of gut, tied on the fingerboard around the instrument's neck, to enable the performer to stop the strings more cleanly.

paragraphs.title: Viol
paragraphs.text: Frets improve consistency of intonation and lend the stopped notes a tone which better matches the open strings.

paragraphs.title: Viol
paragraphs.text: Viols first appeared in Spain in the mid to late 15th century and were most popular in the Renaissance and Baroque (1600-1750) periods.

paragraphs.title: Viol
paragraphs.text: Early ancestors include the Arabic "rebab" and the medieval European vielle, but later, more direct possible ancestors include the Venetian "viole" and the 15th- and 16th-century Spanish "vihuela", a 6-course plucked instrument tuned like a lute (and also like a present-day viol) that looked like but was quite distinct from (at that time) the 4-course guitar (an earlier chordophone).

paragraphs.title: Toy Manchester Terrier
paragraphs.text: The Toy Manchester Terrier is a breed of dog, categorized as a terrier.

paragraphs.title: Toy Manchester Terrier
paragraphs.text: The breed was bred down in size in North America from the Manchester Terrier, and is placed in the Toy Group by the American Kennel Club and the Canadian Kennel Club (the Manchester Terrier is placed in the Terrier Group.)

paragraphs.title: Toy Manchester Terrier
paragraphs.text: Neither the Fédération Cynologique Internationale nor The Kennel Club recognize a Toy variety of the Manchester Terrier.

paragraphs.title: Irish Red and White Setter
paragraphs.text: The Irish Red and White Setter () is a breed of dog, more specifically a setter.

paragraphs.title: Irish Red and White Setter
paragraphs.text: As with all the setters and the Pointer, it is classified as a gundog in the UK and is included in the sporting group in America and Canada.

paragraphs.title: Irish Red and White Setter
paragraphs.text: It is virtually identical in use and temperament to the related Irish Setter and its other setter cousins, the Gordon and English setters, but is more often found as a working gun dog.

paragraphs.title: English Setter
paragraphs.text: The English Setter is a medium size breed of dog.

paragraphs.title: English Setter
paragraphs.text: It is part of the Setter family, which includes the red Irish Setters, Irish Red and White Setters, and black-and-tan Gordon Setters.

paragraphs.title: English Setter
paragraphs.text: The mainly white body coat is of medium length with long silky fringes on the back of the legs, under the belly and on the tail.

paragraphs.title: English Setter
paragraphs.text: The coat features flecks of colour, and the different colour varieties are referred to as belton.

paragraphs.title: Russkiy Toy
paragraphs.text: The Russian Toy (also known as the Russian Toy Terrier, and in Russia as the Russkiy Toy, Toychik,Russian: Русский той, Тойчик ) is a very small breed of dog originally bred in Russia from the English Toy Terrier which is known today as the Manchester Terrier.

paragraphs.title: Russkiy Toy
paragraphs.text: There are two types of coats in the breed: smooth coat and long coat.

paragraphs.title: Russkiy Toy
paragraphs.text: The smooth-coated variety was previously known as the Russian Toy Terrier and long-coated as the Moscow Long Haired Toy Terrier.

paragraphs.title: Russkiy Toy
paragraphs.text: Both were brought together under the same Russian Toy Terrier name in 1988 and the "Terrier" was dropped from the name when the breed was added in 2006 to the official list of breeds registered with the Fédération Cynologique Internationale and has been registered in the Foundation Stock Service of the American Kennel Club since 2008, allowed to compete in AKC companion events since 2010.

paragraphs.title: Russkiy Toy
paragraphs.text: The first official breed standard of the two varieties was written in 1966 in Russia.

paragraphs.title: Teddy Roosevelt Terrier
paragraphs.text: The Teddy Roosevelt Terrier is a small to medium-sized American hunting terrier.

paragraphs.title: Teddy Roosevelt Terrier
paragraphs.text: Lower-set with shorter legs, more muscular, and heavier bone density than its cousin the American Rat Terrier.

paragraphs.title: Teddy Roosevelt Terrier
paragraphs.text: There is much diversity in the history of the Teddy Roosevelt Terrier breed and it shares a common early history with the American Rat Terrier, Fox Paulistinha and Tenterfield Terrier.

paragraphs.title: Teddy Roosevelt Terrier
paragraphs.text: It is said the Rat Terrier background stems from the terriers or other dogs that were brought over by early English and other working class immigrants.

paragraphs.title: Teddy Roosevelt Terrier
paragraphs.text: Since the breed was a farm, hunting and utility dog there was little to no planned breeding other than breeding dogs with agreeable traits to each other in order to produce the desired work ethic in the dog.

paragraphs.title: Teddy Roosevelt Terrier
paragraphs.text: It is assumed that the Feist (dog), Bull Terrier, Smooth Fox Terrier, Manchester Terrier, Whippet, Italian Greyhound, the now extinct English White Terrier, Turnspit dog and or Wry Legged Terrier all share in the Teddy Roosevelt Terrier's ancestry.

paragraphs.title: Teddy Roosevelt Terrier
paragraphs.text: These early Ratting Terriers were then most likely bred to the Beagle or Beagle cross bred dogs (for increased scenting ability) and other dogs.

paragraphs.title: Teddy Roosevelt Terrier
paragraphs.text: Maximizing the influences from these various breeds provides the modern Teddy Roosevelt Terrier with a keen sense of awareness and prey drive, an acute sense of smell and a very high intellect.

paragraphs.title: Teddy Roosevelt Terrier
paragraphs.text: Although they tend to be aloof with strangers they are devoted companion dogs with a strong desire to please and be near their owners side at all times.

paragraphs.title: Feist (dog)
paragraphs.text: A Feist is a small hunting dog, descended from the terriers brought over to the United States by English miners and other working class immigrants.

paragraphs.title: Feist (dog)
paragraphs.text: These terriers probably included crosses between the Smooth Fox Terrier, the Manchester Terrier and the now extinct English White Terrier.

paragraphs.title: Feist (dog)

question: The battle in which Giuseppe Arimondi lost his life secured what for Ethiopia?

paragraphs.title: Outline of Ethiopia
paragraphs.text: Ethiopia is a landlocked sovereign country located in the Horn of Africa.

paragraphs.title: Outline of Ethiopia
paragraphs.text: Ethiopia is bordered by Eritrea to the north, Sudan to the west, South Sudan to the south-west, Kenya to the south, Somalia to the east and Djibouti to the north-east.

paragraphs.title: Outline of Ethiopia
paragraphs.text: Ethiopia is one of the oldest countries in the world and Africa's second-most populous nation.

paragraphs.title: Outline of Ethiopia
paragraphs.text: Ethiopia has yielded some of humanity's oldest traces, making the area important in the history of human evolution.

paragraphs.title: Outline of Ethiopia
paragraphs.text: Recent studies claim that the vicinity of present-day Addis Ababa was the point from which human beings migrated around the world.

paragraphs.title: Outline of Ethiopia
paragraphs.text: Ethiopian dynastic history traditionally began with the reign of Emperor Menelik I in 1000 BC.

paragraphs.title: Outline of Ethiopia
paragraphs.text: The roots of the Ethiopian state are similarly deep, dating with unbroken continuity to at least the Aksumite Empire (which adopted the name "Ethiopia" in the 4th century) and its predecessor state, D`mt (with early 1st millennium BC roots).

paragraphs.title: Outline of Ethiopia
paragraphs.text: After a period of decentralized power in the 18th and early 19th centuries known as the Zemene Mesafint ("Era of the Judges/Princes"), the country was reunited in 1855 by Kassa Hailu, who became Emperor Tewodros II, beginning Ethiopia's modern history.

paragraphs.title: Outline of Ethiopia
paragraphs.text: Ethiopia's borders underwent significant territorial expansion to its modern borders for the rest of the century, especially by Emperor Menelik II and Ras Gobena, culminating in its victory over the Italians at the Battle of Adwa in 1896 with the military leadership of Ras Makonnen, and ensuring its sovereignty and freedom from colonization.

paragraphs.title: Outline of Ethiopia
paragraphs.text: It was brutally occupied by Benito Mussolini's Fascist Italy from 1936 to 1941, ending with its liberation by British Empire and Ethiopian Patriot forces.

paragraphs.title: P'ent'ay
paragraphs.text: P'ent'ay (from Amharic: , also transliterated as Pentay or Pente) is an Amharic and Tigrinya language term for a Christian of a Protestant denomination, widely used in Ethiopia and among Ethiopians and Eritreans living abroad.

paragraphs.title: P'ent'ay
paragraphs.text: The term was coined in the late 1960s and was used as a pejorative for churches that believed in the Pentecostal experience.

paragraphs.title: P'ent'ay
paragraphs.text: Today, it is used to describe local Protestant Christians who are not members of the Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo and Eritrean Orthodox Tewahedo churches.

paragraphs.title: P'ent'ay
paragraphs.text: The term "P'ent'ay" is a shortening of the word "Pentecostal"; however, it is widely used when referring to all Protestant Christians whether they are actual Pentecostals or not.

paragraphs.title: P'ent'ay
paragraphs.text: Some Orthodox will also apply the term to the small Catholic population of Ethiopia.

paragraphs.title: P'ent'ay
paragraphs.text: The equivalent rendition in many other languages is Evangelicals.

paragraphs.title: P'ent'ay
paragraphs.text: The four major Evangelical denominations in Ethiopia are: the Kale Heywet (Word of Life); Mekane Yesus (Place of Jesus), Lutheran; Mulu Wongel (Full Gospel) and Meserete Kristos (meaning "Christ foundation") or Mennonite.

paragraphs.title: P'ent'ay
paragraphs.text: Some P'ent'ay communities - especially Mekane Yesus - have been influenced by the Orthodox Tewahedo Church, which represents mainstream, traditional Ethiopian Christianity.

paragraphs.title: P'ent'ay
paragraphs.text: But for the most part they are very Pentecostal in their worship and theology.

paragraphs.title: Herbert S. Lewis
paragraphs.text: Herbert S. Lewis (born May 8, 1934) is Professor Emeritus of Anthropology at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, where he taught from 1963 to 1998.

paragraphs.title: Herbert S. Lewis
paragraphs.text: He has conducted extensive field research.

paragraphs.title: Herbert S. Lewis
paragraphs.text: In Ethiopia, Lewis studied both the history of the Oromo (Galla) Kingdom of Jimma Abba Jifar and the lives of contemporary Oromos from 1958–60 and in 1965–66.

paragraphs.title: Herbert S. Lewis
paragraphs.text: (Many of his ethnographic photographs are visible in the University of Wisconsin's Digital Library.

paragraphs.title: Herbert S. Lewis
paragraphs.text: See the link to Africa Focus below).

paragraphs.title: Herbert S. Lewis
paragraphs.text: His work in Ethiopia was concerned above all with political leadership and community organization as well as ethnohistory and culture history.

paragraphs.title: Herbert S. Lewis
paragraphs.text: The book, originally titled A Galla Monarchy: Jimma Abba Jifar, Ethiopia, 1830-1932, is a study of the nature of the monarchy, the sources of the ruler's power, as well as its origins.

paragraphs.title: Herbert S. Lewis
paragraphs.text: The study in 1965-66 centered on community life and the leadership of spirit mediums, k'allu, who effectively organized religious life and conflict resolution, and provided a degree of political leadership for rural districts.

paragraphs.title: Second Battle of Agordat
paragraphs.text: The Second Battle of Agordat was fought in late December 1893, between Italian colonial troops and Mahdists from the Sudan.

paragraphs.title: Second Battle of Agordat
paragraphs.text: Emir Ahmed Ali campaigned against the Italian forces in eastern Sudan and led about 10–12,000 men east from Kassala.

paragraphs.title: Second Battle of Agordat
paragraphs.text: This force encountered 2,400 Italians and their Eritrean askaris at Agordat, west of Asmara, commanded by Colonel Arimondi.

paragraphs.title: Second Battle of Agordat
paragraphs.text: Over 1,000 Dervishes, including the Emir, were killed in severe fighting.

paragraphs.title: Second Battle of Agordat
paragraphs.text: The outcome of the battle constituted:

paragraphs.title: Treaty of Addis Ababa
paragraphs.text: The Treaty of Addis Ababa, signed 23 October 1896, formally ended the First Italo–Ethiopian War on terms mostly favorable to Ethiopia.

paragraphs.title: Treaty of Addis Ababa
paragraphs.text: This treaty superseded a secret agreement between Ethiopia and Italy negotiated days after the decisive Battle of Adwa in March of the same year, in which Ethiopian forces commanded by Menelik II defeated the Italians.

paragraphs.title: Treaty of Addis Ababa
paragraphs.text: The most important concession the Italians made was the abrogation of the Treaty of Wuchale and recognizing Ethiopia as an independent country.

paragraphs.title: Ethiopia–Japan relations
paragraphs.text: Ethiopia–Japan relations are the international relations between Ethiopia and Japan.

paragraphs.title: Ethiopia–Japan relations
paragraphs.text: Both were nations with an ancient history which successfully repulsed European military advances to dominate them, Ethiopia at the Battle of Adwa, and Japan at the Battle of Tsushima, and as a result both nations considered each other potential allies prior to World War II.

paragraphs.title: First Italo-Ethiopian War
paragraphs.text: The First Italo-Ethiopian War was fought between Italy and Ethiopia from 1895 to 1896.

paragraphs.title: First Italo-Ethiopian War
paragraphs.text: It originated from a disputed treaty which, the Italians claimed, turned the country into an Italian protectorate.

paragraphs.title: First Italo-Ethiopian War
paragraphs.text: Italy was supported by the two other triple alliance members Germany and Austria.

paragraphs.title: First Italo-Ethiopian War
paragraphs.text: Much to their surprise, they found that Ethiopian ruler Menelik II, rather than being opposed by some of his traditional enemies, was supported by them, so the Italian army, invading Ethiopia from Italian Eritrea in 1893, faced a more united front than they expected.

paragraphs.title: First Italo-Ethiopian War
paragraphs.text: In addition, Ethiopia was supported by Russia, an Orthodox Christian nation like Ethiopia with military advisers, army training, and the sale of weapons for Ethiopian forces during the war.

paragraphs.title: First Italo-Ethiopian War
paragraphs.text: Ethiopia was also supported diplomatically by the United Kingdom and France in order to prevent Italy from becoming a colonial competitor.

paragraphs.title: First Italo-Ethiopian War
paragraphs.text: Full-scale war broke out in 1895, with Italian troops having initial success until Ethiopian troops counterattacked Italian positions and besieged the Italian fort of Meqele, forcing its surrender.

paragraphs.title: First Italo-Ethiopian War
paragraphs.text: Italian defeat came about after the Battle of Adwa, where the Ethiopian army dealt the heavily outnumbered Italians a decisive blow and forced their retreat back into Eritrea.

paragraphs.title: Battle of Adwa
paragraphs.text: The Battle of Adwa (Amharic: አድዋ; Amharic translated: Adowa, or sometimes by the Italian name "Adua") was fought on 2 March 1896/Yekatit 23, 1889 according to Ethiopian calendar between the Ethiopian Empire and the Kingdom of Italy near the town of Adwa, Ethiopia, in Tigray.

paragraphs.title: Battle of Adwa
paragraphs.text: This climactic battle of the First Italo-Ethiopian War, was a decisive defeat for Italy and secured Ethiopian sovereignty.

paragraphs.title: Giuseppe Arimondi
paragraphs.text: Giuseppe Edoardo Arimondi, OSML, OMS, OCI (Savigliano, 26 April 1846 – Adwa, 1 March 1896) was an Italian general, mostly known for his role during the First Italo-Ethiopian War.

paragraphs.title: Giuseppe Arimondi
paragraphs.text: He was one of the few European commanders who gained a victory over the Mahdists before Kitchener's Expedition, soundly defeating them at Agordat in 1893.

paragraphs.title: Giuseppe Arimondi
paragraphs.text: After a long and successfull colonial service, he died in combat at Adwa, and was posthumously awarded the Gold Medal of Military Valor.

paragraphs.title: Ephigenia of Ethiopia
paragraphs.text: Saint Ephigenia of Ethiopia or Iphigenia of Ethiopia (Spanish: "Efigênia" ; Portuguese: "Ifigênia" ; French: "Iphigénie" ; ), also called Iphigenia of Abyssinia (1st century), is a folk saint whose life is told in the "Golden Legend" as a virgin converted to Christianity and then consecrated to God by St. Matthew the Apostle, who was spreading the Gospel to the region of "Ethiopia", which in this case is understood to be located in the regions south of the Caspian Sea, either in one of the provinces of Mesopotamia (Assyria and Babylon), or in Ancient Armenia (Colchis).

paragraphs.title: President pro tempore of the United States Senate
paragraphs.text: The president pro tempore of the United States Senate ( or ), also president pro tem, is the second-highest-ranking official of the United States Senate.

paragraphs.title: President pro tempore of the United States Senate
paragraphs.text: of the United States Constitution provides that the Vice President of the United States is, despite not being a senator, the President of the Senate, and mandates that the Senate must choose a president "pro tempore" to act in the Vice President's absence.

paragraphs.title: President pro tempore of the United States Senate
paragraphs.text: Unlike the vice president, the president pro tempore is an elected member of the Senate, able to speak or vote on any issue.

paragraphs.title: President pro tempore of the United States Senate
paragraphs.text: Selected by the Senate at large, the president pro tempore has enjoyed many privileges and some limited powers.

paragraphs.title: President pro tempore of the United States Senate
paragraphs.text: During the vice president's absence, the president pro tempore is empowered to preside over Senate sessions.

paragraphs.title: President pro tempore of the United States Senate
paragraphs.text: In practice, neither the vice president nor the president pro tempore usually presides; instead, the duty of presiding officer is rotated among junior senators of the majority party to give them experience in parliamentary procedure.

paragraphs.title: Robert Nyce

paragraphs.title: Robert Nyce

paragraphs.title: Robert Nyce

paragraphs.title: Robert Nyce

paragraphs.title: Robert Nyce
paragraphs.text: Following the campaign, he was hired as the Executive Director of the Pennsylvania Independent Regulatory Review Commission (IRRC).

paragraphs.title: Robert Nyce
paragraphs.text: Mr. Nyce served for eight years in that capacity overseeing two major revisions to the Regulatory Review Act and many significant regulatory issues facing the residents of Pennsylvania.

paragraphs.title: Robert Nyce
paragraphs.text: The PA IRRC reviews all regulations promulgated in PA and provides citizens an opportunity to comment on and affect those regulations prior to their promulgation by the state agency that authored the regulation.

paragraphs.title: Robert Nyce
paragraphs.text: The two exceptions are the PA Fish and Boat Commission and the PA Game Commission which remain outside the regulatory review process.

paragraphs.title: Robert Nyce
paragraphs.text: In 2005, Mr. Nyce retired from state government and now resides in Northampton County.

paragraphs.title: Robert Nyce

paragraphs.title: Robert Nyce

paragraphs.title: Robert Nyce

paragraphs.title: Executive Order 10925
paragraphs.text: Executive Order 10925, signed by President John F. Kennedy on March 6, 1961, required government contractors to "take affirmative action to ensure that applicants are employed and that employees are treated during employment without regard to their race, creed, color, or national origin."

paragraphs.title: Executive Order 10925
paragraphs.text: It established the President's Committee on Equal Employment Opportunity (PCEEO), which was chaired by then Vice President Lyndon Johnson.

paragraphs.title: Executive Order 10925
paragraphs.text: Vice Chair and Secretary of Labor Arthur Goldberg was in charge of the Committee's operations.

paragraphs.title: Executive Order 10925
paragraphs.text: This first implementation of Affirmative Action was meant to give equal opportunities in the workforce to all U.S. citizens, not to give special treatment to those discriminated against.

paragraphs.title: Gore-Chernomyrdin Commission
paragraphs.text: The Gore-Chernomyrdin Commission, or U.S.-Russian Joint Commission on Economic and Technological Cooperation, was a United States and Russian Joint Commission developed to increase cooperation between the two countries in several different areas.

paragraphs.title: Gore-Chernomyrdin Commission
paragraphs.text: The Commission was developed by the United States’ President Bill Clinton and Russian President Boris Yeltsin at a summit in Vancouver in April 1993.

paragraphs.title: Gore-Chernomyrdin Commission
paragraphs.text: Al Gore, the United States Vice President, and Victor Chernomyrdin, the Russian Prime Minister, were appointed as co-chairmen, and the committee derives its name from those two individuals.

paragraphs.title: Gore-Chernomyrdin Commission
paragraphs.text: Before his appointment to the Commission, Chernomyrdin oversaw the Soviet national oil industry as minister from 1985-1989.

paragraphs.title: Gore-Chernomyrdin Commission
paragraphs.text: After the fall of the Soviet Union, Chernomyrdin organized the Soviet oil industry into the Gazprom corporation.

paragraphs.title: Alfred Balk
paragraphs.text: Alfred Balk (July 24, 1930 – November 25, 2010) was an American reporter, nonfiction author and magazine editor who wrote groundbreaking articles about housing segregation, the Nation of Islam, the environment and Illinois politics.

paragraphs.title: Alfred Balk
paragraphs.text: His refusal to identify a confidential source led to a landmark court case.

paragraphs.title: Alfred Balk
paragraphs.text: During a career-long emphasis on media improvement, he served on the Twentieth Century Fund's task force that established a National News Council, consulted for several foundations, served as secretary of New York Governor Nelson Rockefeller's Committee on the Employment of Minority Groups in the News Media, and produced a film, "That the People Shall Know: The Challenge of Journalism", narrated by Walter Cronkite.

paragraphs.title: Alfred Balk
paragraphs.text: He wrote and co-authored books on a variety of topics, ranging from the tax exempt status of religious organizations to globalization to the history of radio.

paragraphs.title: Gerald Ford
paragraphs.text: Gerald Rudolph Ford Jr. (born Leslie Lynch King Jr.; July 14, 1913 – December 26, 2006) was an American politician who served as the 38th President of the United States from August 1974 to January 1977, following the resignation of Richard Nixon.

paragraphs.title: Gerald Ford
paragraphs.text: Prior to this he served eight months as the 40th Vice President of the United States, following the resignation of Spiro Agnew.

paragraphs.title: Gerald Ford
paragraphs.text: He was the first person appointed to the vice presidency under the terms of the 25th Amendment, and consequently the only person to have served as both Vice President and President of the United States without being elected to executive office.

paragraphs.title: Gerald Ford
paragraphs.text: Before his appointment to the vice presidency, Ford served 25 years as U.S. Representative from Michigan's 5th congressional district, the final nine of them as the House Minority Leader.

paragraphs.text: It is the main administrative, cultural and geographical centre for East Lothian, which as a result of late-nineteenth century Scottish local government reforms, actually took the form of the county of Haddingtonshire for the period from 1889-1921.

paragraphs.text: St. Mary's Priory, North Berwick, was a monastery of nuns in medieval East Lothian, Scotland.

paragraphs.title: St. Mary's Priory (Lothian)
paragraphs.text: Founded by Donnchad I, Earl of Fife (owner of much of northern East Lothian) around 1150, the priory lasted for more than four centuries, declining and disappearing after the Scottish Reformation.

paragraphs.title: Chrome, Smoke & BBQ
paragraphs.text: Chrome, Smoke & BBQ is a box set by American blues-rock band ZZ Top, released in 2003.

paragraphs.title: Chrome, Smoke & BBQ
paragraphs.text: At the time of release, this box set was notable for using the original mixes for all of the tracks from the band's first five albums for the first time on the CD format.

paragraphs.title: Chrome, Smoke & BBQ
paragraphs.text: This box set, and the companion release "Rancho Texicano", were the only two CD releases which featured original mixes from "ZZ Top's First Album", "Rio Grande Mud", and "Tejas", aside from 1977's "The Best of ZZ Top" which features two tracks from "Rio Grande Mud" and one track from "First Album". "

paragraphs.title: Chrome, Smoke & BBQ
paragraphs.text: Tres Hombres" and "Fandango!

paragraphs.title: Chrome, Smoke & BBQ
paragraphs.text: " were reissued in their original mixes in 2006, and in 2013, Warner Brothers released the CD box set 'The Complete Studio Albums 1970-1990' which includes the first ten ZZ Top studio albums, all with the original mixes.

paragraphs.title: Back to Mono (1958–1969)
paragraphs.text: Back to Mono (1958–1969) is a box set (4 compact discs or 5 vinyl LPs) compilation of the recorded work of record producer Phil Spector, through the 1960s, released in 1991 by ABKCO as #7118-2.

paragraphs.title: Back to Mono (1958–1969)
paragraphs.text: The first track, "To Know Him Is to Love Him," released in 1958, features Spector performing as part of the group the Teddy Bears.

paragraphs.title: Back to Mono (1958–1969)
paragraphs.text: Initially a vinyl album-sized package, the box contained a booklet with photographs, complete song lyrics, discographical information, and a reproduction of the essay on Spector by Tom Wolfe, "The First Tycoon of Teen."

paragraphs.title: Back to Mono (1958–1969)
paragraphs.text: The package also contained a small, round, red "Back to Mono" pin.

paragraphs.title: Trash Box
paragraphs.text: Trash Box is a 5-CD box set of mid-1960s garage rock and psychedelic rock recordings, primarily by American bands.

paragraphs.title: Trash Box
paragraphs.text: This box set is similar to the earlier "Pebbles Box" (a 5-LP box set) and includes almost all of the same recordings in that box set (and in the same order), along with numerous bonus tracks at the end of each disc.

paragraphs.title: Trash Box
paragraphs.text: Supposedly, "the Trash Box" collects the first five volumes of the CDs in the Pebbles series (i.e., those released by AIP Records, not to be confused with the 4 earlier CDs that were issued by ESD Records).

paragraphs.title: Trash Box
paragraphs.text: However, as is generally true of the CD reissues of these five volumes (though not nearly to the same extent), the tracks differ significantly on all five discs as compared to both the original Pebbles LPs and the later Pebbles CDs in the corresponding volumes; and the surf rock rarities on "Pebbles, Volume 4" have been eschewed entirely.

paragraphs.title: Trash Box
paragraphs.text: Overall, there are 109 tracks in the box set (excluding the introduction and ending cuts) as compared to 101 songs on the individual CDs and 72 tracks in the "Pebbles Box".

paragraphs.title: Trash Box
paragraphs.text: Although most of the recordings on "the Trash Box" were released at some point on one of the individual Pebbles albums, several of the songs have not appeared elsewhere in the Pebbles series.

paragraphs.title: Trash Box
paragraphs.text: Inexplicably, one of these songs is the well-known hit "I Fought the Law (but the Law Won)" by the Bobby Fuller Four (on Disc Four) – which is also included in the "Pebbles Box" – in place of the much rarer "Wine Wine Wine" by Bobby Fuller that appears on "Pebbles, Volume 2".

paragraphs.title: Mono Masters
paragraphs.text: Mono Masters is a compilation album by the Beatles, and is an alternate, all-mono version of the album "Past Masters".

paragraphs.title: Mono Masters
paragraphs.text: "Mono Masters" was originally a two-CD set included as part of "The Beatles in Mono" box set.

paragraphs.title: Mono Masters
paragraphs.text: The premise of this box set was to compile only Beatles material which was released or prepared for release with a dedicated mono mix (the set excludes later material mixed and released only in stereo, and material whose mono version was simply created as an equal mix of the two channels of the stereo version).

paragraphs.title: Mono Masters
paragraphs.text: As a result, the track listing for "Mono Masters" differs from "Past Masters" on the second half of disc two, omitting some later songs that never had a mono mix ("Old Brown Shoe", "The Ballad of John and Yoko" and "Let It Be"), and adding several songs released on stereo-only albums that had unreleased mono mixes.

paragraphs.title: Mono Masters
paragraphs.text: Tracks 9–12 and 15 were prepared in March 1969 for release as a 7" mono "Yellow Submarine" EP, two months after the release of the similarly titled soundtrack album, but the project was scrapped, although the EP was mastered.

paragraphs.title: Mono Masters
paragraphs.text: Subsequently, the tracks were only released in stereo (and in an electronically produced mono mixdown, or "fold-down", of the stereo mix), while the true mono mixes remained unreleased.

paragraphs.title: Mono Masters
paragraphs.text: "Get Back" (with B-side "Don't Let Me Down") was the final Beatles single mixed for mono format.

paragraphs.title: Mono Masters
paragraphs.text: It was released in the UK in mono, though the US release was in stereo.

paragraphs.title: Mono Masters
paragraphs.text: Thus, the songs that were originally released on stereo singles in the UK are omitted on this release.

question: What type of forum did a former Soviet statesman initiate?
answer: Organizations could come together to address global issues
